name: Mount Tabor
shortDescription: The traditional site of Jesus Christ's Transfiguration‚Äîa dome-shaped mountain in Lower Galilee where Jesus was revealed in divine glory to Peter, James, and John
fullDescription: Mount Tabor (Hebrew: ◊î◊® ◊™◊ë◊ï◊®, Har Tavor; Arabic: ÿ¨ÿ®ŸÑ ÿßŸÑÿ∑Ÿàÿ±, Jabal at-Tur) rises 575 meters (1,886 feet) above the Jezreel Valley in Lower Galilee, Israel, its distinctive dome shape visible for miles across the landscape. Christian tradition since at least the 4th century CE has identified this mountain as the site of Jesus Christ's Transfiguration, one of the most profound theophanic events in the New Testament. According to the Gospel accounts (Matthew 17:1-9, Mark 9:2-8, Luke 9:28-36), Jesus took his disciples Peter, James, and John up a high mountain, where he was transfigured before them‚Äîhis face shining like the sun and his clothes becoming dazzling white. Moses and Elijah appeared alongside Jesus, discussing his approaching death in Jerusalem, and a luminous cloud overshadowed them while God's voice proclaimed, 'This is my beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased; listen to him.' The mountain's sacred significance, however, predates Christianity. In the Hebrew Bible, Mount Tabor marks the boundary between the tribes of Zebulun, Issachar, and Naphtali (Joshua 19:22), and was the site of Deborah and Barak's victory over Sisera's Canaanite army (Judges 4-5). Psalm 89:12 poetically declares, 'Tabor and Hermon joyously praise your name.' The mountain has been a pilgrimage destination since Byzantine times, with the current Franciscan Church of the Transfiguration (completed 1924) built atop the ruins of Crusader, Byzantine, and earlier structures. The Greek Orthodox Church maintains a separate monastery and chapel on the summit. Each August 6, the Feast of the Transfiguration draws thousands of pilgrims who ascend the winding road or hike the ancient pilgrim paths to commemorate the moment when Jesus's divine nature was revealed, offering his disciples‚Äîand through them, all believers‚Äîa glimpse of heavenly glory.

geography.location: Lower Galilee, Northern District, Israel (near Nazareth and Sea of Galilee)

inhabitants.name: Jesus Christ
inhabitants.description: The Son of God who was transfigured in divine glory on Mount Tabor's summit

inhabitants.name: Moses
inhabitants.description: Appeared with Elijah during the Transfiguration, representing the Law

inhabitants.name: Elijah
inhabitants.description: Appeared with Moses during the Transfiguration, representing the Prophets

events.name: Battle of Mount Tabor (c. 1125 BCE)
events.description: Deborah the prophetess and Barak led Israelite forces from Mount Tabor to defeat Sisera's Canaanite army, as recorded in Judges 4-5

events.name: The Transfiguration of Jesus (c. 29-30 CE)
events.description: Jesus took Peter, James, and John up Mount Tabor. He was transfigured before them‚Äîface shining like the sun, clothes brilliant white. Moses and Elijah appeared, and God's voice proclaimed Jesus as His beloved Son

events.name: Byzantine Church Construction (4th-6th century CE)
events.description: Byzantine Christians built churches and monasteries on Mount Tabor's summit, establishing it as pilgrimage site commemorating the Transfiguration

events.name: Crusader Fortress and Church (12th century CE)
events.description: Crusaders fortified Mount Tabor and built Benedictine abbey and church dedicated to the Transfiguration, utilizing earlier Byzantine foundations

events.name: Mamluk Destruction (1263 CE)
events.description: Mamluk Sultan Baybars destroyed the Crusader fortress and churches, leaving the summit in ruins for centuries

events.name: Construction of Modern Church (1919-1924)
events.description: Franciscan Order built current Church of the Transfiguration on summit, designed by Antonio Barluzzi incorporating Byzantine and Crusader ruins

events.name: Annual Feast of Transfiguration (August 6)
events.description: Thousands of Christian pilgrims climb Mount Tabor each August 6 to celebrate the Feast of the Transfiguration with outdoor Mass and processions

mythologyContexts.usage: Site of Jesus's Transfiguration; theophanic revelation of Christ's divine nature; connection between Law (Moses), Prophets (Elijah), and Gospel (Jesus); pilgrimage destination; symbol of theosis (divinization)
names: Jabal at-Tur (Arabic: Mountain of the Mount)

textReferences.context: Detailed account of Transfiguration: Jesus's metamorphosis, appearance of Moses and Elijah, Peter's offer to build tabernacles, God's voice from cloud
Earliest Gospel account emphasizing Jesus's clothes becoming 'dazzling white, such as no one on earth could bleach them'
Account specifying Jesus was praying when transfigured; Moses and Elijah discussed his 'departure' (exodus) to be accomplished in Jerusalem
Peter's testimony: 'We ourselves heard this voice come from heaven, while we were with him on the holy mountain'

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Transfiguration on Mount Tabor represents the supreme theophany of the New Testament‚Äîthe revelation of Jesus's divine nature while still in human form. The event symbolizes: (1) Jesus as fulfillment of Law (Moses) and Prophets (Elijah); (2) the unity of Old and New Covenants; (3) the promise of resurrection and glorification for all believers; (4) the 'already but not yet' nature of the Kingdom‚Äîglory glimpsed but consummation delayed. The shining light (Tabor Light) represents uncreated divine energy, central to Eastern Orthodox theology of theosis (participation in divine nature). Peter's desire to build three tabernacles symbolizes human tendency to preserve momentary spiritual experiences rather than continuing the journey toward the cross. The cloud represents God's presence (Shekinah), echoing Sinai and the Exodus. The event prepares the disciples for Jesus's coming passion by revealing his divine identity.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The Transfiguration has been central to Christian theology, liturgy, and art since early Christianity. The Feast of the Transfiguration (August 6) is celebrated by Catholics, Orthodox, and many Protestant denominations. Eastern Orthodoxy particularly emphasizes the Transfiguration as revealing the possibility of theosis‚Äîhuman participation in divine nature through grace. The event has been depicted by countless artists including Raphael, Fra Angelico, Giovanni Bellini, and Andrei Rublev. Pilgrimage to Mount Tabor has been continuous since Byzantine times, surviving Crusades, Islamic rule, and modern conflicts. The mountain remains a powerful symbol of divine revelation, transformation, and the promise of glorification.

mythologyContexts.usage: Tribal boundary marker; site of Deborah and Barak's victory; poetic symbol of God's creation; geographical landmark in Israel's inheritance

textReferences.context: Deborah commands Barak to gather troops at Mount Tabor to fight Sisera's army; YHWH grants victory
Poetic celebration of victory, one of oldest texts in Hebrew Bible
Mount Tabor as boundary marker for tribe of Issachar's inheritance
'Tabor and Hermon joyously praise your name' ‚Äî mountains as witnesses to God's glory
Prophetic judgment: 'You have been a snare at Mizpah, a net spread upon Tabor'

mythologyContexts.symbolism: In Jewish tradition, Mount Tabor symbolizes God's faithfulness in granting victory to Israel and the proper ordering of the Promised Land through tribal boundaries. The mountain's distinctive dome shape made it an ideal gathering point for military action and tribal assembly. Its mention alongside Mount Hermon in Psalm 89 elevates it as a poetic symbol of creation praising its Creator. The mountain represents God's intervention in history‚Äînot through supernatural miracles but through strategic military positioning and divinely-granted courage.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Mount Tabor holds a place in Jewish historical memory as the site of one of Israel's great military victories during the period of the Judges. Deborah's leadership as prophetess and judge, commanding Barak to action, represents a unique moment of female authority in ancient Israel. The 'Song of Deborah' (Judges 5) is one of the oldest texts in the Hebrew Bible, preserving ancient Hebrew poetry celebrating the triumph. While Mount Tabor is less prominent in Jewish tradition than mountains like Sinai, Zion, or Moriah, it remains part of the sacred geography of the Land of Israel.

etymology.origin: The name 'Tavor' (Hebrew: ◊™◊ë◊ï◊®) is of uncertain etymology. Possible derivations include: (1) From Semitic root *t-b-r related to height, elevation, or 'navel' (center); (2) From Hebrew 'tabbur' (◊ò◊ë◊ï◊®) meaning 'navel' or 'center,' suggesting the mountain as an omphalos or central sacred site; (3) From ancient Canaanite place name preserved in Hebrew. The mountain's distinctive dome shape may have influenced its naming. Greek Septuagint renders it as Thabor (ŒòŒ±Œ≤œéœÅ). Latin Vulgate uses Thabor. Arabic name 'Jabal at-Tur' means 'Mountain of the Mount,' with 'Tur' from Aramaic 'tura' (mountain), same root as Mount Sinai's Arabic name (Jabal Musa or Tur Sina).
etymology.development: Ancient Canaanite name (unknown) ‚Üí Hebrew Tavor (◊™◊ë◊ï◊®) (Biblical period) ‚Üí Greek Thabor (ŒòŒ±Œ≤œéœÅ) (Septuagint, Hellenistic) ‚Üí Latin Thabor (Vulgate) ‚Üí Arabic Jabal at-Tur (ÿ¨ÿ®ŸÑ ÿßŸÑÿ∑Ÿàÿ±) (Islamic period) ‚Üí Modern: Hebrew Har Tavor, English Mount Tabor

geographical.culturalArea: Historic Galilee / Ancient tribal territories of Zebulun, Issachar, Naphtali

originPoint.name: Mount Tabor Summit, Northern District, Israel
originPoint.description: Mount Tabor rises to 575 meters (1,886 feet) above sea level in Lower Galilee, standing approximately 400 meters above the surrounding Jezreel Valley. The mountain has a distinctive dome or rounded shape, visible from great distances. Located 17 km west of the Sea of Galilee, 10 km east of Nazareth. Summit features Franciscan Church of the Transfiguration (1924) and Greek Orthodox Church and monastery. Accessible by winding road from Arab village of Dabburiya at the base.

firstAttestation.description: First biblical mention in the Book of Judges (Judges 4-5), which describes events from the period of the Judges (c. 1200-1050 BCE). The 'Song of Deborah' (Judges 5) is considered one of the oldest texts in the Hebrew Bible, possibly dating to the 12th century BCE. Archaeological evidence shows settlement and cultic activity in the area from Bronze Age.
firstAttestation.source: Book of Judges (Hebrew Bible); archaeological surveys of Mount Tabor region

historicalDate.display: c. 12th century BCE - Present (continuous sacred significance)

timelinePosition.era: Old Testament history through New Testament theophany to ongoing pilgrimage
timelinePosition.context: Mount Tabor has been significant in biblical history from the period of the Judges (c. 1200 BCE) through Jesus's ministry (c. 30 CE) to continuous Christian pilgrimage spanning nearly 2,000 years. The mountain transitioned from Old Testament military and territorial significance to New Testament theophanic revelation.

keyMoments.significance: Israelite forces gather at Mount Tabor, defeat Sisera's Canaanite army (Judges 4-5)
Jesus transfigured in divine glory before Peter, James, and John; Moses and Elijah appear
Mount Tabor identified as Transfiguration site; first churches constructed on summit
Major Byzantine monastic development; three churches built representing Peter's three tabernacles
Crusaders build fortress and Benedictine abbey; Mount Tabor becomes strategic stronghold
Sultan Baybars destroys Crusader structures; summit left in ruins
Franciscans obtain permission to return; begin rebuilding Christian presence
Franciscan Church of the Transfiguration completed (architect Antonio Barluzzi)
Annual Feast of Transfiguration (August 6) draws thousands; continuous Christian worship
